### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 51 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Journalist: A manufacturers' trade group that has long kept its membership list secret inadvertently sent me a document listing hundreds of manufacturing companies. A representative of the trade group later confirmed that every company listed in the document does indeed belong to the trade group. Because Bruch Industries is not listed on the document, it is evidently not a member of the trade group.
Question: The journalist's reasoning in the argument is flawed in that the journalist
Choices:
  A: gives no reason to think that Bruch Industries would want to belong to the trade group
  B: does not present any evidence that the document names every member of the trade group
  C: does not explain how it is that the trade group could have inadvertently sent out a secret document
  D: presents no reason why Bruch Industries would not want its membership in the trade group to be known
  E: takes for granted the accuracy of a statement by a representative who had a reason to withhold information
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The journalist received a document listing hundreds of manufacturing companies from a manufacturers' trade group.
  The representative of the trade group confirmed that every company listed in the document belongs to the trade group.
  Bruch Industries is not listed on the document.
Thought: 
  The journalist assumes that the document listing hundreds of manufacturing companies is a complete list of all the members of the trade group.
  However, it is possible that the document is incomplete or that there are other ways to become a member of the trade group that do not involve being listed on the document.
  Therefore, the journalist's reasoning is flawed.
  The correct answer is B: does not present any evidence that the document names every member of the trade group.
Criticism: 
  The journalist's reasoning is flawed because the document listing hundreds of manufacturing companies is not necessarily a complete list of all the members of the trade group.
  However, the correct answer is not B, but rather D: presents no reason why Bruch Industries would not want its membership in the trade group to be known.

  However, there may be reasons why Bruch Industries would not want to be a member of the trade group or why it would not want its membership to be known.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 52 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Modest amounts of exercise can produce a dramatic improvement in cardiovascular health. One should exercise most days of the week, but one need only do the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking on those days to obtain cardiovascular health benefits. More vigorous exercise is more effective, but a strenuous workout is not absolutely necessary.
Question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the statements above?
Choices:
  A: Having a strenuous workout most days of the week can produce a dramatic improvement in cardiovascular health.
  B: Doing the equivalent of an hour of brisk walking two or three times a week generally produces dramatic improvements in cardiovascular health.
  C: It is possible to obtain at least as great an improvement in cardiovascular health from doing the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking most days of the week as from having a strenuous workout most days of the week.
  D: Aside from exercise, there is no way of improving one's cardiovascular health.
  E: To obtain a dramatic improvement in one's cardiovascular health, one must exercise strenuously at least occasionally.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Modest amounts of exercise can produce a dramatic improvement in cardiovascular health.
  One should exercise most days of the week.
  One need only do the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking on those days to obtain cardiovascular health benefits.
  More vigorous exercise is more effective, but a strenuous workout is not absolutely necessary.
Thought: 
  The passage suggests that modest amounts of exercise can produce a dramatic improvement in cardiovascular health. 
  It also suggests that one should exercise most days of the week, but only needs to do the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking on those days to obtain cardiovascular health benefits. 
  The passage also states that more vigorous exercise is more effective, but a strenuous workout is not absolutely necessary. 
  Therefore, the statement most strongly supported by the passage is that it is possible to obtain at least as great an improvement in cardiovascular health from doing the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking most days of the week as from having a strenuous workout most days of the week. 
  The answer is C: It is possible to obtain at least as great an improvement in cardiovascular health from doing the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking most days of the week as from having a strenuous workout most days of the week.
Criticism: 
  There is no criticism to this answer as it is the most strongly supported statement by the passage. 
Action: Answer("C")

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 53 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Leatherbacks, the largest of the sea turtles, when subjected to the conditions of captivity, are susceptible to a wide variety of fatal diseases with which they would never come in contact if they lived in the wild. It is surprising, therefore, that the likelihood that a leatherback will reach its theoretical maximum life expectancy is about the same whether that animal is living in captivity or in the wild.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy?
Choices:
  A: Fewer diseases attach leatherbacks than attack other large aquatic reptiles.
  B: The average life expectancy of sea turtles in general is longer than that of almost all other marine animals.
  C: Most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators.
  D: Few zoologists have sufficient knowledge to establish an artificial environment that is conducive to the well-being of captive leatherbacks.
  E: The size of a leatherback is an untrustworthy indicator of its age.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity.
  Leatherbacks have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy in captivity or in the wild.
Thought:
  The apparent discrepancy is that leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity, but they have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy in captivity or in the wild.
  To resolve the discrepancy, we need to find a reason why the susceptibility to fatal diseases in captivity does not affect the likelihood of reaching maximum life expectancy.
  A: This statement is irrelevant to the discrepancy.
  B: This statement is also irrelevant to the discrepancy.
  C: This statement suggests that predators are a significant threat to leatherbacks in the wild, which could explain why the likelihood of reaching maximum life expectancy is the same in captivity and in the wild.
  D: This statement is irrelevant to the discrepancy.
  E: This statement is also irrelevant to the discrepancy.
  Therefore, the best answer is C: Most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  Leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity.
  Leatherbacks have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy in captivity or in the wild.
Thought: 
  There is an apparent discrepancy between the fact that leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity and yet have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy in captivity or in the wild.
  To resolve this discrepancy, we need to find a reason why the susceptibility to fatal diseases in captivity does not affect the likelihood of reaching maximum life expectancy.
  Choice C provides a reason why the susceptibility to fatal diseases in captivity does not affect the likelihood of reaching maximum life expectancy. If most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators, then the fatal diseases that leatherbacks are susceptible to in captivity may not be as significant a factor in determining their maximum life expectancy as predation is in the wild.
  Therefore, the answer is C: Most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators.
Criticism: 
  None.

  Choice E is also irrelevant to the discrepancy.
  Therefore, the best answer is C: Most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators.

  A: Wilke & Wilke have produced more new shows for this season than they produced last season.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 55 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: History provides many examples of technological innovations being strongly resisted by people whose working conditions without those innovations were miserable. This shows that social inertia is a more powerful determinant of human behavior than is the desire for comfort or safety.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the reasoning in the argument?
Choices:
  A: People correctly believe that technological innovations often cause job loss.
  B: People are often reluctant to take on new challenges.
  C: Some examples of technological innovation have been embraced by workers.
  D: People tend to adapt easily to gradually implemented technological innovations.
  E: People correctly believe that technological innovations almost always increase workers' productivity.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument claims that social inertia is a more powerful determinant of human behavior than the desire for comfort or safety.
Thought:
  The argument is based on the premise that people resist technological innovations because of social inertia.
  The argument assumes that people resist technological innovations because they are resistant to change.
  The argument assumes that people do not resist technological innovations because of the desire for comfort or safety.
  To undermine the argument, we need to find an option that suggests that people resist technological innovations for reasons other than social inertia.
  Option A suggests that people resist technological innovations because they cause job loss, which is not related to social inertia.
  Option B suggests that people resist technological innovations because they are reluctant to take on new challenges, which is related to social inertia.
  Option C suggests that some examples of technological innovation have been embraced by workers, which does not undermine the argument.
  Option D suggests that people adapt easily to gradually implemented technological innovations, which does not undermine the argument.
  Option E suggests that people resist technological innovations because they believe that they increase workers' productivity, which is not related to social inertia.
  Therefore, the best answer is A: People correctly believe that technological innovations often cause job loss.
Criticism:
  The argument assumes that people resist technological innovations because of social inertia, but it does not consider other factors that may influence people's behavior.
  The argument also assumes that the desire for comfort or safety is not a significant factor in people's behavior, which may not be true in all cases.
Action: Answer("A")

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 56 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: We can be sure that at least some halogen lamps are well crafted, because halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth. Any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
Question: Which one of the following arguments is most similar in its reasoning to the argument above?
Choices:
  A: We can be confident that the temperature will drop abruptly on at least one day this week, for there is a chance of storms most days this week; whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: We can be positive that there are at least a few disturbing sonnets, given that Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets; everything Melinda writes is disturbing.
  C: We can be sure that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car, because she can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city, and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: We can be positive that at least some minnows are healthy, because many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby, and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: We can be confident that the cornmeal used at Matteo's Trattoria is healthful and organic, since cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals there; whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The argument states that halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth, and any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
  A: The argument states that there is a chance of storms most days this week, and whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: The argument states that Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets, and everything Melinda writes is disturbing.
  C: The argument states that Gianna can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city, and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: The argument states that many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby, and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: The argument states that cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals at Matteo's Trattoria, and whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
Thought: 
  The argument concludes that at least some halogen lamps are well crafted because halogen lamps from most major manufacturers are on display at Furniture Labyrinth, and any item on display at Furniture Labyrinth is well crafted.
  A: The argument concludes that we can be confident that the temperature will drop abruptly on at least one day this week because there is a chance of storms most days this week, and whenever there are storms, the temperature drops suddenly.
  B: The argument concludes that we can be positive that there are at least a few disturbing sonnets because Melinda has written several different kinds of sonnets, and everything Melinda writes is disturbing.
  C: The argument concludes that we can be sure that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car because she can have her car worked on at any of several shops in the city, and every shop is capable of doing good mechanical work.
  D: The argument concludes that we can be positive that at least some minnows are healthy because many different species of minnow can be found in lakes nearby, and every lake nearby is teeming with healthy fish.
  E: The argument concludes that we can be confident that the cornmeal used at Matteo's Trattoria is healthful and organic because cornmeal is among the ingredients used in preparing meals there, and whenever a meal is prepared at Matteo's Trattoria, only healthful, organic ingredients are used.
  The argument in option C is most similar in its reasoning to the argument above.
Criticism: 
  The argument in option C is not a perfect match to the argument above, as the argument above concludes that at least some halogen lamps are well crafted, while the argument in option C concludes that Gianna will get at least some good mechanical work done to her car. However, both arguments use the same reasoning pattern of concluding that at least some items in a group possess a certain quality because all items in the group are capable of possessing that quality.
Action: Answer("C")

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Harrold Foods is attempting to dominate the soft-drink market by promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign. But survey results show that, in the opinion of 72 percent of all consumers, "Hero" already dominates the market. Since any product with more than 50 percent of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market, Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
Question: The argument commits which one of the following errors in reasoning?
Choices:
  A: failing to exclude the possibility that what appears to be the result of a given market condition may in fact be the cause of that condition
  B: mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result
  C: treating the failure to establish that a certain claim is false as equivalent to a demonstration that that claim is true
  D: taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true
  E: describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument states that Harrold Foods dominates the market because "Hero" has more than 50% of the sales in the market.
  The survey results show that 72% of all consumers believe that "Hero" already dominates the market.
Thought:
  The argument assumes that the current market share of "Hero" will remain the same in the future.
  The argument also assumes that the survey results are accurate and that the consumers' opinions reflect the actual market share of "Hero."
  However, the argument does not provide any evidence to support these assumptions.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of E: describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 1:

  The argument does not provide any evidence to support the assumption that the current market share of "Hero" is greater than 50%.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result.
  The correct answer is B: mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result.
Criticism:
  Your analysis is correct.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 58 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Science journalist: Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars. They are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres. Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete. Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed. A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.
Question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the science journalist's statements?
Choices:
  A: Any celestial object without lithium in its atmosphere is a star with less mass than the Sun.
  B: Any celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements.
  C: No celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
  D: No celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has less mass than the Sun.
  E: No celestial object less massive than a brown dwarf has lithium in its atmosphere.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
- Brown dwarfs have more mass than planets but less mass than stars.
- Brown dwarfs are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres.
- Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete.
- Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed.
- A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 59 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A computer game publisher has recently released its latest adventure game. The game's inventive puzzles and compelling plot induce even casual players to become preoccupied with completing it. The game can be purchased from retail outlets or rented for two-day intervals. The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game, saving them a significant portion of the purchase price. Since the rate of sales now meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations, the publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to justify the publisher's prediction?
Choices:
  A: The game can be purchased directly from the publisher as well as from retailers.
  B: It takes several weeks for most players to complete the game.
  C: The publisher's games are among the most popular computer games on the market.
  D: Most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward.
  E: Some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The game can be purchased from retail outlets or rented for two-day intervals.
  The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game.
  The rate of sales now meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations.
Thought: 
  The publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
  To justify this prediction, we need to find an option that supports the idea that people will buy the game after renting it.
  A: This option does not provide any information about whether people will buy the game after renting it.
  B: This option suggests that people will take longer to complete the game, which could mean that they will rent it multiple times before deciding to buy it.
  C: This option suggests that the publisher has a good reputation and a strong fan base, which could increase the likelihood of people buying the game after renting it.
  D: This option suggests that people may not play the game extensively after completing it, which could decrease the likelihood of people buying the game after renting it.
  E: This option suggests that some people may give the game away after completing it, which could decrease the likelihood of people buying the game after renting it.
  Option B suggests that people will rent the game multiple times before deciding to buy it, which could increase the rate of rentals and sales. Therefore, B most helps to justify the publisher's prediction.
Action: Answer("B")

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 60 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Had the party's economic theories been sound and had it succeeded in implementing its program, the inflation rate would have lessened considerably. But because the inflation rate actually increased, the party's economic theories were fur off the mark.
Question: The flawed reasoning in which one oflbe following arguments most closely resembles the flawed reasoning in the argument above?
Choices:
  A: If the people who inhabited the valley for so long had been invaded, or iflbere had been a dramatic climatic change, there would have been chaoges in the valley's architecture. But architecture in the valley remained the same throughout their stay. Thus, the valley people must not have been invaded at any time during their stay.
  B: Many people fear that iflbe opposition party wins the election and keeps its promise to cut wages dramatically, workers in key industries will strike. But because the workers have promised not to strike, these workers must think the party will not keep its promise of a dramatic wage cut.
  C: If the company had succeeded in selling its subsidiaries and used the cash to purchase the new patent, its stock price would have doubled in the last two years. But the price oflbe stock did not increase in that time. Thus, the company must have failed to sell its subsidiaries.
  D: City residents were expected to show a great deal of support for the rebels iflbe battle was won and the jailed rebel leaders freed. Residents have shown a great deal of support or the rebels for the last three days. Therefore, the rebels must have won the battle.
  E: Iflbe television station's new wealber forecasting equipment had been worth the investment, the accuracy of its forecasts would have risen, along wilb its ratings. But the station's ratings actually decreased. Thus, the new equipment is no improvement on the old.

  The argument states that if the party's economic theories were sound and implemented, the inflation rate would have decreased. However, since the inflation rate increased, the party's economic theories were off the mark.
  A: The argument states that if the valley people were invaded or there was a climatic change, there would have been changes in the valley's architecture. But since the architecture remained the same, the valley people must not have been invaded.
  B: The argument states that many people fear that if the opposition party wins the election and keeps its promise to cut wages dramatically, workers in key industries will strike. But since the workers have promised not to strike, these workers must think the party will not keep its promise of a dramatic wage cut.
  C: The argument states that if the company had succeeded in selling its subsidiaries and used the cash to purchase the new patent, its stock price would have doubled in the last two years. But since the price of the stock did not increase in that time, the company must have failed to sell its subsidiaries.
  D: The argument states that city residents were expected to show a great deal of support for the rebels if the battle was won and the jailed rebel leaders freed. Since residents have shown a great deal of support for the last three days, the rebels must have won the battle.
  E: The argument states that if the television station's new weather forecasting equipment had been worth the investment, the accuracy of its forecasts would have risen, along with its ratings. But since the station's ratings actually decreased, the new equipment is no improvement on the old.

  The argument states that if the party's economic theories were sound and implemented, the inflation rate would have decreased. However, since the inflation rate increased, the party's economic theories were off the mark.
  This is similar to option C, which states that if the company had succeeded in selling its subsidiaries and used the cash to purchase the new patent, its stock price would have doubled in the last two years. But since the price of the stock did not increase in that time, the company must have failed to sell its subsidiaries.
  Both arguments make a conditional statement, but the conclusion is based on the opposite of what was expected to happen.

This argument assumes that the only reason for the decrease in ratings is the new equipment, which may not be accurate.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 61 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Government official: Residents who are foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries. This is wise, since cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens, and no one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform. Moreover, a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable. So, ____.
Question: Which one of the following most logically completes the government official's statement?
Choices:
  A: foreign citizens who serve as public servants should be granted citizenship in the country they serve
  B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries
  C: only former cabinet undersecretaries should be appointed as cabinet secretaries
  D: foreign citizens should be eligible to serve as cabinet secretaries
  E: cabinet undersecretaries should not be expected to stand in for cabinet secretaries
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The government official believes that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries.
  Cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  No one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform.
  A cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
Thought:
  The government official believes that cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  Therefore, it would be illogical to appoint foreign citizens as cabinet secretaries.
  Moreover, a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
  Therefore, it would be illogical to appoint foreign citizens as cabinet undersecretaries as well.
  The statement should logically complete by stating that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
  The answer is B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
Criticism:
  There is no logical reason to assume that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
  The government official only stated that cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  Therefore, it is possible that foreign citizens could perform the duties of a cabinet undersecretary without issue.
  The statement should logically complete by stating that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries.
  The answer is D: foreign citizens should be eligible to serve as cabinet secretaries.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries.
  Cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  No one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform.
  A cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
Thought: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries.
  The official believes that cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  Therefore, it would not be wise to appoint foreign citizens as cabinet secretaries.
  The official also believes that a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
  Therefore, it would be wise to appoint someone who is eligible to serve as cabinet secretary as a cabinet undersecretary.
  The statement that most logically completes the government official's argument is B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
Criticism: 
  The statement "foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries" does not logically complete the government official's argument.
  The official believes that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries.
  The official also believes that a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
  Therefore, it would be wise to appoint someone who is eligible to serve as cabinet secretary as a cabinet undersecretary.
  The correct answer is D: foreign citizens should be eligible to serve as cabinet secretaries.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries.
  Cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  No one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform.
  A cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
Thought: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries.
  The official also believes that a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
  If a foreign citizen is appointed as a cabinet undersecretary, then that person may have to perform duties that they should not perform as a non-citizen.
  Therefore, the most logical statement to complete the government official's argument is that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
  The answer is B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
Criticism: 
  The argument assumes that all foreign citizens are not eligible for citizenship in the country they serve.
  The argument also assumes that all cabinet undersecretaries are foreign citizens.
  Therefore, the argument may not be valid in all cases.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 3:
Knowledge: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries.
  Cabinet secretaries perform some duties that should be performed only by citizens.
  No one should be appointed to a position if it involves duties that person should not perform.
  A cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
Thought: 
  The government official believes that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries.
  The official also believes that a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable.
  If the official believes that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet secretaries, then it would make sense for the official to believe that foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries either.
  Therefore, the statement that most logically completes the government official's argument is B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries.
Action: Answer("B")

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 62 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Figorian Wildlife Commission: The development of wetlands in industrialized nations for residential and commercial uses has endangered many species. To protect wildlife we must regulate such development in Figoria: future wetland development must be offset by the construction of replacement wetland habitats. Thus, development would cause no net reduction of wetlands and pose no threat to the species that inhabit them. Figorian Development Commission: Other nations have flagrantly developed wetlands at the expense of wildlife. We have conserved. Since Figorian wetland development might not affect wildlife and is necessary for growth, we should allow development. We have as much right to govern our own resources as countries that have already put their natural resources to commercial use.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if accepted, would most strongly support the Figorian Development Commission's position against the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position?
Choices:
  A: National resources should be regulated by international agreement when wildlife is endangered.
  B: The right of future generations to have wildlife preserved supersedes the economic needs of individual nations.
  C: Only when a reduction of populations of endangered species by commercial development has been found should regulation be implemented to prevent further damage.
  D: Environment regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment.
  E: It is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The Figorian Wildlife Commission wants to regulate wetland development in Figoria to protect wildlife.
  The Figorian Development Commission believes that wetland development is necessary for growth and that Figoria has the right to govern its own resources.
Thought: 
  The Figorian Development Commission's position is that Figoria has the right to govern its own resources and that wetland development is necessary for growth. 
  Therefore, a principle that supports the right of nations to govern their own resources would most strongly support the Figorian Development Commission's position against the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position.
  The principle that supports this position is D: Environment regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment.
Criticism: 
  The principle that supports the Figorian Development Commission's position is not necessarily D. 
  D does not directly address the issue of a nation's right to govern its own resources.
  A more appropriate principle might be one that emphasizes a nation's sovereignty over its own resources.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")

Topic: Law
Context: Columnist: Although most people favor the bill and the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights, it will not be passed for many years, if at all; nor will any similar bill. Those people who would be adversely affected were it to become law are very influential. This shows that, if this country is a democracy at all, it is not a well-functioning one.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the columnist's reasoning?
Choices:
  A: In a well-functioning democracy, any bill that would benefit most people will be passed into law within a few years if it does not violate anyone's basic human rights.
  B: If a democracy is well functioning, then any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law.
  C: In a well-functioning democracy, a bill that is favored by most people will become law within a few years only if those who oppose it are not very influential.
  D: Any bill passed into law in a well-functioning democracy will be favored by most people and be consistent with individuals' basic human rights.
  E: A bill that most people favor will be passed promptly into law in a well-functioning democracy if the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 64 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Editorial: The premier's economic advisor assures her that with the elimination of wasteful spending the goal of reducing taxes while not significantly decreasing government services can be met. But the premier should not listen to this advisor, who in his youth was convicted of embezzlement. Surely his economic advice is as untrustworthy as he is himself, and so the premier should discard any hope of reducing taxes without a significant decrease in government services.
Question: Which one of the following is a questionable argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument?
Choices:
  A: rejecting a proposal on the grounds that a particular implementation of the proposal is likely to fail
  B: trying to win support for a proposal by playing on people's fears of what could happen otherwise
  C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself
  D: taking lack of evidence for a claim as evidence undermining that claim
  E: presupposing what it sets out to establish
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The editorial argues that the premier should not listen to her economic advisor because he was convicted of embezzlement in his youth.
  A: This choice is not relevant to the argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument.
  B: This choice is not relevant to the argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument.
  C: The editorial criticizes the economic advisor himself rather than examining the economic advice he provides.
  D: This choice is not relevant to the argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument.
  E: The editorial presupposes that the economic advisor's advice is untrustworthy and that reducing taxes without significantly decreasing government services is impossible.
Thought: 
  The editorial argues that the premier should not listen to her economic advisor because he was convicted of embezzlement in his youth.
  The editorial does not examine the economic advice the advisor provides.
  The editorial presupposes that the economic advisor's advice is untrustworthy and that reducing taxes without significantly decreasing government services is impossible.
  Therefore, the questionable argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument is criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself.
  The answer is C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself.
Criticism: 
  Your analysis is correct.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 65 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Biologist: Humans have five fingers because we descended from a fish with five phalanges in its fins. Despite our prejudices to the contrary, our configuration of fingers is no more or less useful than several other possible configurations, e.g., six per hand. So, if humans had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins and had six fingers on each hand, then we would be just as content with that configuration.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the biologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Everyone is equally content with our present configuration of fingers.
  B: Humans are never equally content with two things of unequal usefulness.
  C: Humans are always equally content with two things of equal usefulness.
  D: The perceived usefulness of our configuration of fingers is an illusory result of our prejudices.
  E: At least one species of fish had six phalanges in its fins.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
- The biologist argues that humans could have had six fingers per hand if they had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins.
- The biologist argues that our configuration of fingers is no more or less useful than several other possible configurations.
- The biologist argues that our prejudices lead us to believe that our configuration of fingers is the best.
Thought:
- The biologist's argument is that humans could have had six fingers per hand if they had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins.
- The argument is that our configuration of fingers is no more or less useful than several other possible configurations.
- Therefore, if there is evidence that humans are content with other configurations of fingers, it would strengthen the biologist's argument.
- Choice A does not strengthen the argument because it does not provide evidence that humans are content with other configurations of fingers.
- Choice B weakens the argument because it suggests that humans are never content with two things of unequal usefulness, which contradicts the biologist's argument.
- Choice C does not strengthen the argument because it is a general statement that does not provide evidence that humans are content with other configurations of fingers.
- Choice D strengthens the argument because it suggests that our perception of the usefulness of our configuration of fingers is based on our prejudices, which supports the biologist's argument that our configuration of fingers is not inherently better than other configurations.
- Choice E does not strengthen the argument because it only provides evidence that a fish with six phalanges in its fins exists, but it does not provide evidence that humans could have had six fingers per hand.
Criticism:
- Choice D strengthens the argument, but it does not directly provide evidence that humans are content with other configurations of fingers.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 66 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Dried parsley should never be used in cooking, for it is far less tasty and healthful than fresh parsley is.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most clearly helps to justify the argument above?
Choices:
  A: Fresh ingredients should be used in cooking whenever possible.
  B: Only the tastiest ingredients should ever be used in cooking.
  C: Ingredients that should never be used in cooking are generally neither tasty nor healthful.
  D: Parsley that is not both tasty and healthful should never be used in cooking.
  E: In cooking, dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument claims that dried parsley should never be used in cooking because it is less tasty and healthful than fresh parsley.
  A: This principle suggests that fresh ingredients should be used whenever possible, but it does not necessarily support the argument that dried parsley should never be used.
  B: This principle suggests that only the tastiest ingredients should be used, but it does not necessarily support the argument that dried parsley should never be used.
  C: This principle suggests that ingredients that should never be used are generally neither tasty nor healthful, which supports the argument that dried parsley should never be used.
  D: This principle suggests that parsley that is not both tasty and healthful should never be used, but it does not necessarily support the argument that dried parsley should never be used.
  E: This principle suggests that dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients, which supports the argument that dried parsley should never be used.

  Principle C suggests that ingredients that should never be used are generally neither tasty nor healthful, which supports the argument that dried parsley should never be used.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 67 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Detective: Because the embezzler must have had specialized knowledge and access to internal financial records, we can presume that the embezzler worked for XYZ Corporation as either an accountant or an actuary. But an accountant would probably not make the kind of mistakes in ledger entries that led to the discovery of the embezzlement. Thus it is likely that the embezzler is one of the actuaries.
Question: Each of the following weakens the detective's argument EXCEPT:
Choices:
  A: The actuaries' activities while working for XYZ Corporation were more closely scrutinized by supervisors than were the activities of the accountants.
  B: There is evidence of breaches in computer security at the time of the embezzlement that could have given persons outside XYZ Corporation access to internal financial records.
  C: XYZ Corporation employs eight accountants, whereas it has only two actuaries on its staff.
  D: An independent report released before the crime took place concluded that XYZ Corporation was vulnerable to embezzlement.
  E: Certain security measures at XYZ Corporation made it more difficult for the actuaries to have access to internal financial records than for the accountants.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The detective presumes that the embezzler worked for XYZ Corporation as either an accountant or an actuary.
  The detective argues that the embezzler is likely one of the actuaries because an accountant would not make the kind of mistakes that led to the discovery of the embezzlement.
Thought:
  A: If the activities of the actuaries were more closely scrutinized, it would be less likely that one of them could have embezzled money without being detected. This weakens the detective's argument.
  B: If someone outside the corporation had access to internal financial records, it would be possible for them to embezzle money without being an accountant or an actuary. This weakens the detective's argument.
  C: This fact does not directly weaken the detective's argument.
  D: The fact that XYZ Corporation was vulnerable to embezzlement does not directly weaken the detective's argument.
  E: If security measures made it more difficult for the actuaries to have access to internal financial records, it would be less likely that one of them could have embezzled money. This weakens the detective's argument.
  Therefore, the answer is C: XYZ Corporation employs eight accountants, whereas it has only two actuaries on its staff.
Criticism:
  The fact that XYZ Corporation employs more accountants than actuaries does not directly weaken the detective's argument. However, it does not support the detective's argument either.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 68 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: One should not play a practical joke on someone if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
Question: The principle stated above, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in which one of the following arguments?
Choices:
  A: I should not have played that practical joke on you yesterday. Even if it was not contemptuous, I should have realized that it would bring significant harm to someone.
  B: I have no reason to think that the practical joke I want to play would harm anyone. So, since the joke would show no contempt for the person the joke is played on, it would not be wrong for me to play it.
  C: Because of the circumstances, it would be wrong for me to play the practical joke I had intended to play on you. Even though it would not show contempt for anyone, it could easily bring you significant harm.
  D: It would have been wrong for me to play the practical joke that I had intended to play on you. Even though I did not have reason to think that it would significantly harm anyone, I did think that it would show contempt for someone.
  E: Someone was harmed as a result of my practical joke. Thus, even though it did not show contempt for the person I played the joke on, I should not have played it.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 69 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A film makes a profit if the number of people who see it is sufficient to generate revenues from ticket sales greater than the amount spent to make it. Hence, the primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film. However, it is not the primary goal of television executives to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives?
Choices:
  A: More people are willing to see a film more than once than are willing to watch a television show more than once.
  B: There is no analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
  D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows are shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  A: More people are willing to see a film more than once than are willing to watch a television show more than once.
  B: There is no analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
  D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows are shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch.
Thought:
  Movie executives want to maximize the number of people who see a film to generate revenues from ticket sales.
  Television executives do not want to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  Option A is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Option B is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Option C is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Option D is relevant because it explains that television executives are concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show because sponsors make their profits from them.
  Option E is not relevant to the goals of the executives.
  Therefore, the answer is D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
Criticism:
  The explanation in option D is not the only reason why television executives do not want to maximize the number of viewers for their shows. There could be other reasons such as the type of content, target audience, and competition.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  Movie executives aim to maximize the number of people who see a film to make a profit.
  Television executives do not aim to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
Choices:
  A: More people are willing to see a film more than once than are willing to watch a television show more than once.
    This choice does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.
  B: There is no analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers.
    This choice does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
    This choice explains the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives. Since the cost of producing a film is much greater than the cost of producing an hour of television, movie executives need to maximize the number of people who see a film to make a profit. In contrast, television executives can make a profit with fewer viewers because the cost of producing a television show is much lower.
  D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
    This choice does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows are shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch.
    This choice does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.
Thought:
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film to make a profit.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  The cost of producing a film is much greater than the cost of producing an hour of television.
  Therefore, the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives is explained by the fact that movie executives need to maximize the number of people who see a film to make a profit, while television executives can make a profit with fewer viewers because the cost of producing a television show is much lower.
Action: Answer("C")

  Movie executives aim to maximize the number of people who see a film to generate revenues from ticket sales.

  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  If sponsors are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show, it explains why television executives do not aim to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  Therefore, the answer is D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
Criticism:
  None.
Action: Answer("D")
Votes: D, C, D, D, D, D, D, D, D, D
Agent Answer: D
Correct Answer: D
Score: 1

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 70 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Curator: Our museum displays only twentieth-century works, which are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection. Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store. The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Question: If the curator's statements are true, which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Every print in the museum store is of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection.
  B: Every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work.
  C: There are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector.
  D: Hopper's Nighthawks is both a twentieth-century work and a work on loan to the museum from a private collector.
  E: Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
  The works are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
  Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store.
  The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Thought: 
  The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
  Prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
  The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection.
  Therefore, some prints in the museum store are not of works displayed in the museum.
  Therefore, C cannot be true.
  The museum store sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
  Therefore, B cannot be true.
  Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection.
  Therefore, D cannot be true.
  Every print in the museum store is of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection.
  Therefore, A must be true.
  Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum.
  Therefore, E must be true.
Action: Answer("A")

- The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
- The works are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
- Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store.

- Hopper's Nighthawks is a work that is not part of the museum's permanent collection.
- This statement is true based on the information given.
- Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum.
- This statement is not necessarily true based on the information given.

- The conclusion that there are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector is not necessarily true based on the information given. It is possible that the museum store does not sell prints of some works that are displayed in the museum.

- The works are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
- Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store.
- The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.

Thought:
- Every print in the museum store is either a print of a work on loan from a private collector or a print of a work in the museum's permanent collection.
- Every work in the museum is either on loan from a private collector or in the museum's permanent collection.
- Therefore, every print in the museum store is a print of a work that is displayed in the museum.
- Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection.
- Therefore, Hopper's Nighthawks is not available as a print in the museum store if the curator's statements are true.

Criticism:
- The conclusion that every print in the museum store is a print of a work that is displayed in the museum is not necessarily true. The curator's statements only say that prints of all of the works in the museum's permanent collection are available in the museum store, not that every print in the museum store is of a work in the museum.
- The conclusion that Hopper's Nighthawks is not available as a print in the museum store is correct, but it is not one of the answer choices.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 71 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it. However, in some cases a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it. For example, a person should never be blamed for unwittingly bringing about misfortune if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Question: The principles above, if valid, most help to justify the reasoning in which one of the following?
Choices:
  A: Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to Riley that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. So, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. So, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  D: When Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, he did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. So, if no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  E: Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Thus, even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage states that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Thought: 
  Choice A: Riley did not realize that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. If he could not have reasonably foreseen this, he should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Choice B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. If she could not have reasonably foreseen this, she should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Choice C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. This does not align with the principle stated in the passage because Gougon was concerned that it might make his guests ill, indicating that he could have reasonably foreseen the possibility.
  Choice D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine and did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. If he could not have reasonably foreseen this, he should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Choice E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves, which any reasonable person could have foreseen would start a fire. This does not align with the principle stated in the passage because any reasonable person could have foreseen the possibility.
Conclusion: 
  Choices A, B, and D align with the principle stated in the passage. 
  Choices C and E do not align with the principle stated in the passage.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The principles state that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street without realizing that it could lead to a traffic accident.
  B: Oblicek suggested to her brother to take out a loan to expand his business without knowing that it was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt.

  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine without knowing that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm without realizing that it could start a fire.

  The principles state that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street without realizing that it could lead to a traffic accident. If he could not have reasonably foreseen that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident, he should not be blamed for it.
  B: Oblicek suggested to her brother to take out a loan to expand his business without knowing that it was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt. If she could not have reasonably foreseen that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, she should not be blamed for it.
  C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests without any reason to think that it would make them ill. If he could not have reasonably foreseen that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, he should not be blamed for it.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine without knowing that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. If he could not have reasonably foreseen that giving the wrong medicine would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure, he should not be blamed for it.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm without realizing that it could start a fire. However, any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Therefore, Kapp should be blamed for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm.
  The principles above most help to justify the reasoning in A, B, C, and D, but not in E.

This choice is inconsistent with the principle stated in the passage.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 72 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: People who have specialized knowledge about a scientific or technical issue are systematically excluded from juries for trials where that issue is relevant. Thus, trial by jury is not a fair means of settling disputes involving such issues.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
Choices:
  A: The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
  B: The more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
  C: Appointing an impartial arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues, because arbitrators tend to favor settlements in which both parties compromise on the issues.
  D: Experts who give testimony on scientific or technical issues tend to hedge their conclusions by discussing the possibility of error.
  E: Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The argument is that people with specialized knowledge are excluded from juries for trials involving scientific or technical issues, making trial by jury unfair for such disputes.
  A: The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
  B: The more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
  C: Appointing an impartial arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues, because arbitrators tend to favor settlements in which both parties compromise on the issues.
  D: Experts who give testimony on scientific or technical issues tend to hedge their conclusions by discussing the possibility of error.
  E: Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
Thought: 
  The argument is that trial by jury is not fair for disputes involving scientific or technical issues because jurors with specialized knowledge are excluded.
  Option A weakens the argument by suggesting that jurors without specialized knowledge may not be able to comprehend the testimony, even if it is explained to them.
  Option B does not weaken the argument, as it suggests that jurors with specialized knowledge may be biased.
  Option C is irrelevant to the argument, as it suggests that appointing an arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues.
  Option D is also irrelevant to the argument, as it discusses how experts give testimony, not how juries are selected.
  Option E is also irrelevant to the argument, as it discusses the cost of expert witnesses, not how juries are selected.
  Therefore, the best answer is A: The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given. 
Criticism: 
  There is no criticism to this answer.

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 73 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Richard: Because it fails to meet the fundamental requirement of art—that it represent—abstract art will eventually be seen as an aberration. Jung-Su: Although artists, like musicians, may reject literal representation, makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects, which are discovered only when everyday perspectives are rejected. Thus, whatever others might come to say, abstract art is part of the artistic mainstream.
Question: Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether
Choices:
  A: makers of abstract art reject literal representation
  B: the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent
  C: musicians may reject literal representation
  D: abstract art will be seen as an aberration
  E: abstract art is representational
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Richard argues that abstract art fails to meet the fundamental requirement of art, which is to represent.
  Jung-Su argues that makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects, which are discovered only when everyday perspectives are rejected.
Thought:
  Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent.
  Richard argues that it is, while Jung-Su argues that makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects.
  Therefore, the answer is B: the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent.
Criticism:
  Your thought process is correct.
Action: Answer("B")

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 74 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Geologist: The dominant view that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals deep in the earth's crust has been challenged by scientists who hold that it formed, not from living material, but from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth. But their theory is refuted by the presence in petroleum of biomarkers, molecules indicating the past or present existence of a living organism.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the geologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Fossils have been discovered that are devoid of biomarkers.
  B: Living organisms only emerged long after the earth's formation.
  C: It would take many millions of years for organisms to become petroleum.
  D: Certain strains of bacteria thrive deep inside the earth's crust.
  E: Some carbon deposits were formed from the fossilized remains of plants.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The geologist argues that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals deep in the earth's crust.
  Some scientists challenge this view and argue that petroleum formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  The geologist's argument is supported by the presence of biomarkers in petroleum, which indicate the past or present existence of a living organism.
Thought: 
  The geologist's argument is that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  The opposing view is that petroleum formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  The geologist's argument is supported by the presence of biomarkers in petroleum.
  To weaken the geologist's argument, we need to find an answer choice that weakens the link between the presence of biomarkers and the formation of petroleum from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  Answer choice A weakens the geologist's argument by showing that fossils can exist without biomarkers, which suggests that the absence of biomarkers in petroleum does not necessarily mean that it did not form from living material.
  Answer choice B is irrelevant to the argument.
  Answer choice C strengthens the opposing view by suggesting that it would take many millions of years for organisms to become petroleum, which supports the idea that petroleum formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  Answer choice D is irrelevant to the argument.
  Answer choice E strengthens the opposing view by suggesting that some carbon deposits were formed from the fossilized remains of plants, which supports the idea that petroleum formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  Therefore, the best answer is A: Fossils have been discovered that are devoid of biomarkers.
Criticism: 
  The answer is correct. Answer choice A weakens the geologist's argument by showing that fossils can exist without biomarkers, which suggests that the absence of biomarkers in petroleum does not necessarily mean that it did not form from living material.
  However, it is worth noting that the opposing view, that petroleum formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth, is not necessarily strengthened by this answer choice. 
Action: Answer("A")

### Temperature: 2.0 | Problem 75 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: City leader: If our city adopts the new tourism plan, the amount of money that tourists spend here annually will increase by at least $2 billion, creating as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would. It would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant here, but adopting the tourism plan would cost less.
Question: The city leader's statements, if true, provide the most support for which one of the following
Choices:
  A: The city should implement the least expensive job creation measures available.
  B: In general, it is reasonable for the city to spend money to try to convince manufacturing companies to build plants in the city.
  C: The city cannot afford both to spend money to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city and to adopt the new tourism plan.
  D: It would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
  E: The only way the city can create jobs is by increasing tourism.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will increase the amount of money that tourists spend in the city annually by at least $2 billion.
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will create as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would.
Thought: 
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will increase the amount of money that tourists spend in the city annually by at least $2 billion.
  The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will create as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would.
  The city leader believes that it would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant here.
  The city leader believes that adopting the tourism plan would cost less than convincing an automobile manufacturer to build a plant here.
  Therefore, the city leader believes that it would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
  The answer is D: It would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
Criticism: 
  The city leader's statements do not necessarily provide support for the idea that the city should implement the least expensive job creation measures available (A).
  The city leader's statements do not necessarily provide support for the idea that it is reasonable for the city to spend money to try to convince manufacturing companies to build plants in the city in general (B).
  The city leader's statements do not necessarily provide support for the idea that the city cannot afford both to spend money to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city and to adopt the new tourism plan (C).
  The city leader's statements do not necessarily provide support for the idea that the only way the city can create jobs is by increasing tourism (E).
Action: Answer("D")
